Today I voted with the government, on their changes to the Winter Fuel Allowance policy. This change involves making the allowance more targeted, so it only goes to those in receipt of pension credits.
This was not a decision I took lightly and I know not everyone is happy with it. I want to explain my thinking.
There were two key questions which I have particularly reflected upon prior to this vote:
My belief is that the pension credit is a fair threshold to stop this happening. But the key thing is that everyone eligible is receiving it. There are reportedly 880,000 people entitled but not claiming – which not only means they will not get the Winter Fuel Allowance, but they will not get the pension credit itself or get other things, like discounts on council tax. The government is also extending the Household Support Fund for the next 6 months because it is a lifeline for people who are struggling with the cost of living. MPs like myself have a role to play in raising awareness of these things. You can write to my office if you are in need of help checking eligibility with either: [email protected]
On this question I look to some of the other things going on at the level of national government. The energy price cap will be £117 lower at the end of this year than in 2023. The state pension went up £900 in April (much faster than working-age benefits). The triple-lock is in place and Labour are 100% committed to it. So I am satisfied that the Winter Fuel Allowance changes, difficult as they are, are offset by significant other forms of pensioner support.
Clearly in an ideal world a Labour government would not be making this change. We introduced the Winter Fuel Allowance in the first place, in 1997.
However, the legacy we were left by the last government means hard choices are needed. The money needed to fill the £22bn black hole which Chancellor Rachel Reeves has identified will need to come from somewhere.
The alternative, if we bury our heads in the sand, is that we potentially see a collapse of confidence in the UK economy, across markets. The deficit could grow dramatically. Growth could slow further and public services become even more stretched.
I do not see this as viable.
The question then becomes not ‘if’ we fill the black hole, but ‘how’. Being in government is, in the end, about being the one who makes this choice. And already some of the easier options – from taxing energy giants to removing non-dom status – have been deployed.
Regardless of the rationale, I can understand that any change to the Winter Fuel Allowance will feel worrying, given that it is for pensioners. Anyone who has an older relative can identify with this – particularly with the nights drawing in.
So I think we need to be really clear that this policy is about means testing the allowance – not abolishing it. It removes the ‘universal’ element, which currently means the allowance is paid regardless of how much money and assets pensioners have.
This is still not ideal, at a time when everyone is feeling the pinch. But I believe it is justifiable, with public finances and services as stretched as they are.
Keir Starmer said recently that things may get worse before they get better. This is obviously not the news we wanted to hear. But it indicates both an honesty and a focus on the long-term which I believe is refreshing in politics, given what we have witnessed these past few years.
I therefore see the Winter Fuel Allowance changes, whilst not something anyone wanted to have to do, as a decision for the long term. This is about taking immediate action to steady the economy and turn around the tanker. It is not a decision taken in isolation. Is a prerequisite to the steps which are clearly needed for the future of country – to rebuild public services and get our economy growing.
This is how I viewed the decisions the government took, and this is why I voted the way I did.
Bayo Alaba
MP for Southend East and Rochford

I recently had the pleasure of visiting Achievement Through Football (ATF), an inspiring organisation dedicated to supporting communities across South Essex at risk of isolation. ATF creates positive pathways for engagement through sport, catering to a diverse range of groups, including offenders, young families, and individuals learning English as a second language. Their work is vital in fostering inclusivity and community spirit.
During my visit, I was delighted to meet the dedicated ATF team. Their commitment to empowering individuals and creating opportunities for engagement through sport is truly commendable. As your MP, I am eager to support their initiatives and amplify their message.
I later referenced this important work in my speech in the House of Commons, highlighting ATF’s significant strides in my constituency of Southend East and beyond. Their grassroots efforts utilise sport as a powerful tool to heal and unite communities, particularly among those at risk of exclusion. I discussed the transformative potential of sport, especially for individuals who have encountered challenges within the criminal justice system. Since my election, we have seen multiple incidents of knife crime and anti-social behaviour in our community, which can have frightening and potentially fatal consequences.
Sport often serves as a critical intervention point for young people, equipping them with essential life skills such as determination, teamwork, and resilience. It provides an opportunity for youth to reconnect with their communities and build positive relationships.
Drawing on my own experiences as an amateur football manager, I shared how I witnessed the impact of grassroots sports firsthand. As part of a leadership team in one of Europe’s largest amateur football clubs, we nurtured young talent from our community. Many of these young players faced significant challenges and were often drawn into negative influences. The support and camaraderie found in a football team not only shaped their lives but also provided a positive and encouraging environment.
It is an honour to pay tribute to the success of ATF and to emphasise the importance of local grassroots organisations that use sport to reduce crime and anti-social behaviour. These organisations offer young people a second chance, allowing them to rebuild their lives and contribute positively to society.
Thank you for your continued support in recognising the vital role of community engagement through sport. Together, we can ensure that organisations like ATF continue to thrive and make a positive impact in our communities.

I recently attended the launch of an important report, Securing the Future of Council Housing, which outlines a vision to protect and revitalise council housing across the country. As an MP, council housing is an issue that I am deeply committed to supporting because I believe that everyone deserves a safe and comfortable place to call home. For over a century, council homes have provided that foundation for millions of families, but today, we face significant challenges that demand urgent action.
The need for truly affordable and secure housing has never been more critical. Currently, a record 109,000 households in England live in temporary accommodation, highlighting the dire shortage of council housing. This lack of supply is straining government finances as well—between 2021 and 2026, private landlords are set to receive £70 billion in housing benefits due to the shortfall of affordable options.
In response to this crisis, twenty of England’s largest council landlords released an interim report earlier this year with recommendations for the new government. Encouragingly, the Deputy Prime Minister has since pledged a ‘council housing revolution,’ promising new investment, rent stability, and a review of Right to Buy policies. However, while these announcements are welcome, much more needs to be done to secure a sustainable future for council housing.
The financial model underpinning council housing is broken, with a projected £2.2 billion deficit in councils’ housing budgets by 2028. This is largely due to the failure to uphold a 2012 agreement between the government and councils. While councils were expected to deliver on their commitments, repeated changes in central government policies have imposed new costs and restrictions, making it increasingly difficult for councils to meet their obligations.
The Housing Revenue Account (HRA) system is now in a precarious state, and a simple rent settlement will not be enough to fix it. Without immediate intervention to stabilise its foundations, many council landlords will struggle to maintain existing homes, meet new safety and energy standards, or build new social housing. Instead, some councils may be forced to sell off their remaining stock, further reducing the availability of council homes.
The report offers a comprehensive, practical plan for how councils can work with the government over the next decade to safeguard the future of council housing. It calls for urgent steps to stabilise the system, including a £644 million emergency capital injection to offset income lost due to recent rent caps. This funding would provide short-term relief, allowing councils to continue investing in housing maintenance and development.
Looking ahead, the report proposes key measures for the next government spending review:
These recommendations lay out a bold yet achievable path to stabilise the council housing system, improve living conditions, and build the next generation of council homes. As an MP, I am committed to advocating for these changes and working closely with the government to ensure that our communities have the housing they deserve.
The future of council housing is at a critical juncture, but with the right support and decisive action, we can restore stability to the system and provide a secure, affordable home for every family that needs one. I look forward to working together with local authorities, council landlords, and the government to make this vision a reality. It’s time to secure the future of council housing for the benefit of all.
If you care about the future of council housing and want to understand the full scope of the challenges and solutions, I encourage you to read the full report. As the election draws near, I have been working hard on the campaign trail, and this past week was particularly special as I was joined by my family. My wife, our two sons, and our daughter have been incredibly supportive to me throughout this journey, and I can’t begin to describe how important their encouragement has been.
Seeing my family helping out on the campaign trail filled me with immense pride. Their presence and enthusiasm reminded me why I am working so hard to bring about change. Balancing family time with the demands of the campaign hasn’t been easy, but their unwavering support has made all the difference.
Labour’s commitment to supporting families through key principles resonates deeply with me, especially as a parent. Here are some of the key policies we are championing:
Bringing Back the Family Doctor and Improving Local NHS Care
Labour’s health policy is centered on transforming the NHS into a Neighbourhood Health Service. We will cut red tape to free up GPs, allowing them more time with patients. Patients will have the option to see the same GP at each appointment, and we will trial Neighbourhood Health Centres, which will bring together family doctors, district nurses, care workers, physiotherapists, and mental health specialists under one roof.
Free Breakfast Clubs in Every Primary School in England
Labour plans to improve school attendance by introducing breakfast clubs for all primary school children in England. This initiative will give every child the best start to their school day and provide parents with more choices about work, paving the way for a modern childcare system.
It was wonderful to share these policies with the people of Southend while having my family by my side. Their support and the support of our community are what drive me to work even harder.
Family life is essential for everyone. It provides a foundation of love, support, and stability that helps us all thrive. Labour’s policies are designed to strengthen families and communities, ensuring that everyone has the opportunity to build a better future together. By focusing on education, healthcare, and support for working parents, we are committed to creating a society where families can flourish and every individual can achieve their full potential.
